rule_english: If a nun gives the full admission to an unmarried girl who is more than twenty years old, but who has not trained in the six rules for two years, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she gives the full admission to an unmarried girl who is more than twenty years old, and who has trained in the six rules for two years; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
notes: Monks, approval is required for an unmarried girl who is eighteen years old to train in the six rules for two years.
formulas bmc 1: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. This unmarried girl so-and-so, who is eighteen years old and training under Venerable so-and-so, is asking the Sangha for approval to train in the six rules for two years. If the Sangha is ready, it should give approval to the unmarried girl so-and-so who is eighteen years old to train in the six rules for two years. This is the motion.  Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. This unmarried girl so-and-so, who is eighteen years old and training under Venerable so-and-so, is asking the Sangha for approval to train in the six rules for two years. The Sangha gives approval to the unmarried girl so-and-so who is eighteen years old to train in the six rules for two years. Any nun who approves of giving approval to the unmarried girl so-and-so who is eighteen years old to train in the six rules for two years should remain silent. Any nun who doesn’t approve should speak up.  The Sangha has given approval to the unmarried girl so-and-so who is eighteen years old to train in the six rules for two years. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus

english_name: Ordaining Trained Unmarried Girls Without Approval
rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī paripuṇṇavīsativassaṁ kumāribhūtaṁ dve vassāni chasu dhammesu sikkhitasikkhaṁ saṅghena asammataṁ vuṭṭhāpeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun gives the full admission to an unmarried girl who is more than twenty years old and who has trained for two years in the six rules, but who has not been approved by the Sangha, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she gives the full admission to an unmarried girl who is more than twenty years old, who has trained in the six rules for two years, and who has been approved by the Sangha; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Monks, approval is required for the full admission of an unmarried girl who is more than twenty years old and who has trained for two years in the six rules
formulas bmc 1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. This unmarried girl so-and-so, who is more than twenty years old and who has trained for two years in the six rules under Venerable so-and-so, is asking the Sangha for approval to be fully admitted. If the Sangha is ready, it should give approval for the unmarried girl so-and-so, who is more than twenty years old and who has trained for two years in the six rules under Venerable so-and-so, to be fully admitted. This is the motion.  Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. This unmarried girl so-and-so, who is more than twenty years old and who has trained for two years in the six rules under Venerable so-and-so, is asking the Sangha for approval to be fully admitted. The Sangha gives approval for the unmarried girl so-and-so, who is more than twenty years old and who has trained for two years in the six rules under Venerable so-and-so, to be fully admitted. Any nun who approves of giving approval for the unmarried girl so-and-so, who is more than twenty years old and who has trained for two years in the six rules under Venerable so-and-so, to be fully admitted should remain silent. Any nun who doesn’t approve should speak up.  The Sangha has given approval for the unmarried girl so-and-so, who is more than twenty years old and who has trained for two years in the six rules under Venerable so-and-so, to be fully admitted. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī ūnadvādasavassā vuṭṭhāpeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun who has less than twelve years of seniority gives the full admission, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if one who has twelve years of seniority gives the full admission; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.

english_name: Twelve Years of Seniority Without Approval
rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī paripuṇṇadvādasavassā saṅghena asammatā vuṭṭhāpeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun who has twelve years of seniority gives the full admission without approval from the Sangha, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she has twelve years of seniority, has been approved by the Sangha, and then gives the full admission; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
notes: Monks, approval is required for a nun who has twelve years of seniority to give the full admission Venerables, I, the nun so-and-so who has twelve years of seniority, ask the Sangha for approval to give the full admission.’  And she should ask a second and a third time.  The Sangha should then decide whether that nun is competent and has a sense of conscience.  If she is ignorant and shameless, approval should not be given. If she is ignorant but has a sense of conscience, approval should not be given. If she is competent but shameless, approval should not be given. If she is competent and has a sense of conscience, approval should be given.
formulas bmc 1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so, who has twelve years of seniority, is asking the Sangha for approval to give the full admission. If the Sangha is ready, it should give approval to nun so-and-so, who has twelve years of seniority, to give the full admission. This is the motion.  Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so, who has twelve years of seniority, is asking the Sangha for approval to give the full admission. The Sangha gives approval to nun so-and-so, who has twelve years of seniority, to give the full admission. Any nun who approves of giving approval to nun so-and-so, who has twelve years of seniority, to give the full admission should remain silent. Any nun who doesn’t approve should speak up.  The Sangha has given approval to nun so-and-so, who has twelve years of seniority, to give the full admission. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī—‘alaṁ tāva te, ayye, vuṭṭhāpitenā’ti vuccamānā ‘sādhū’ti paṭissuṇitvā pacchā khīyanadhammaṁ āpajjeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun is told, “Venerable, you’ve given enough full admissions for now,” and she consents, saying, “Fine,” but then criticizes it afterwards, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she criticizes one who regularly acts out of favoritism, ill will, confusion, or fear; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī sikkhamānaṁ—‘sace me tvaṁ, ayye, cīvaraṁ dassasi, evāhaṁ taṁ vuṭṭhāpessāmī’ti vatvā, sā pacchā anantarāyikinī neva vuṭṭhāpeyya na vuṭṭhāpanāya ussukkaṁ kareyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun tells a trainee nun, “If you give me a robe, Venerable, I’ll give you the full admission,” but she then neither gives her the full admission nor makes any effort to have her fully admitted, then, if there were no obstacles, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if there is an obstacle; if she searches for someone to give her the full ordination, but is unable to find anyone; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
notes: If she thinks, “I’ll neither give her the full admission nor make any effort to have her fully admitted,” then by the mere fact of abandoning her duty, she commits an offense entailing confession.

english_name: Not Ordaining Trainees After She Follows
rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī sikkhamānaṁ— ‘sace maṁ tvaṁ, ayye, dve vassāni anubandhissasi evāhaṁ taṁ vuṭṭhāpessāmī’ti vatvā, sā pacchā anantarāyikinī neva vuṭṭhāpeyya na vuṭṭhāpanāya ussukkaṁ kareyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun tells a trainee nun, “If you follow me for two years, Venerable, I’ll give you the full admission,” but she then neither gives her the full admission nor makes any effort to have her fully admitted, then, if there were no obstacles, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if there is an obstacle; if she searches for someone to give her the full ordination, but is unable to find anyone; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
notes: If she thinks, “I’ll neither give her the full admission nor make any effort to have her fully admitted,” then by the mere fact of abandoning her duty, she commits an offense entailing confession.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī purisasaṁsaṭṭhaṁ kumārakasaṁsaṭṭhaṁ caṇḍiṁ sokāvāsaṁ sikkhamānaṁ vuṭṭhāpeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun gives the full admission to a trainee nun who is socializing with men and boys and who is temperamental and difficult to live with, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she gives her the full admission without knowing what she is like; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Men: those who have reached twenty years of age. Boys: those who have not reached twenty years of age. Socializing: she socializes with improper bodily and verbal actions. Temperamental: angry is what is meant. Difficult to live with: she causes suffering to others, and grieves herself.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī mātāpitūhi vā sāmikena vā ananuññātaṁ sikkhamānaṁ vuṭṭhāpeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun gives the full admission to a trainee nun who has not been given permission by her parents or her husband, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she gives her the full admission without knowing; if she gives her the full admission after permission has been given; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Parents: the biological parents is what is meant. Husband: he who possesses her. Who has not been given permission: who has not asked permission.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī pārivāsikachandadānena sikkhamānaṁ vuṭṭhāpeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If, when a given consent has expired, a nun gives the full admission to a trainee nun, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she gives her the full admission while the gathering has not yet left; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: When a given consent has expired: when the gathering has left.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī anuvassaṁ vuṭṭhāpeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun gives full admission every year, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she gives full admission every other year; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī ekaṁ vassaṁ dve vuṭṭhāpeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun gives the full admission to two women in one year, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she gives the full admission to one woman every other year; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā chattupāhanaṁ dhāreyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun who is not sick uses a sunshade and sandals, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she is sick; if she uses them in a monastery or in the vicinity of a monastery; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Who is not sick: who is comfortable without a sunshade and sandals. Who is sick: who is not comfortable without a sunshade and sandals. A sunshade: there are three kinds of sunshades: the white sunshade, the reed sunshade, the leaf sunshade. They are bound at the rim and bound at the ribs. Uses: if she uses them even once, she commits an offense entailing confession.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā yānena yāyeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun who is not sick travels in a vehicle, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Who is not sick: who is able to travel on foot. Who is sick: who is unable to travel on foot. A vehicle: a wagon, a carriage, a cart, a chariot, a palanquin, a litter. Travels: if she travels in a vehicle even once, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī saṅghāṇiṁ dhāreyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun wears a hip ornament, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she wears it because she is sick; if she wears a girdle; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
notes: A hip ornament: whatever goes on the hip.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī itthālaṅkāraṃ dhāreyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a nun wears jewellery, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she does it because she is sick; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
offense_factors_bmc: Jewellery: what goes on the head, what goes around the neck, what goes on the hands, what goes on the feet, what goes around the hips.
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī gandhavaṇṇakena nahāyeyya,  pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: Should any bhikkhuni (not being ill) bathe with perfumes  and scents, it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: if she does it because she is sick; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī vāsitakena piññākena nahāyeyya,  pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: Should any bhikkhuni (not being ill) bathe with scented  sesame powder, it is to be confessed
no_offense_factors: if she does it because she is sick; if she bathes with ordinary oilseed flour; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā ummaddāpeyya vā parimaddāpeyya vā, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun has a nun massage her or rub her, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī sikkhamānāya ummaddāpeyya vā parimaddāpeyya vā, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun has a trainee nun massage her or rub her, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī  sāmaṇeriyā ummaddāpeyya vā parimaddāpeyya vā, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun has  a novice nun  massage her or rub her, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī gihiniyā ummaddāpeyya vā parimaddāpeyya vā, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun has a female householder massage her or rub her, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhussa purato anāpucchā āsane nisīdeyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun sits down on a seat in front of a monk without asking permission, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she sits down on the seat after asking permission; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Sits down on a seat: even if she sits down on the ground, she commits an offense entailing confession.

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī anokāsakataṁ bhikkhuṁ pañhaṁ puccheyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun asks a question of a monk who has not given her permission, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if she asks after getting permission; if she gets permission, but not in regard to a specific subject, and she then asks about any subject; if she is insane; if she is the first offender.
notes: Asks a question: if she gets permission to ask about the discourses, but she asks about the Monastic Law or philosophy, she commits an offense entailing confession. If she gets permission to ask about the Monastic Law, but she asks about the discourses or philosophy, she commits an offense entailing confession. If she gets permission to ask about philosophy, but she asks about the discourses or the Monastic Law, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Yā pana bhikkhunī asaṅkaccikā gāmaṁ paviseyya, pācittiyan
rule_english: If a nun enters an inhabited area without wearing her chest wrap, she commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if her robe is stolen; if her robe is lost; if she is sick; if she is not mindful; if she does not know; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: sampajānamusāvāde pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk lies in full awareness, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: who misrepresents the truth unintentionally like speaking quickly and saying one thing while meaning another.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Intention: the aim to misrepresent the truth; and 2) Effort: the effort to make another individual know whatever one wants to communicate based on that aim
notes: falsehoods conveyed not only by speech but also by writing or gesture or silence
formulas bmc 1: Cv 4 14.30 Senior confesses : C: Ahaṁ āvuso sambahulā nānā-vatthukāyo dukkaṭāyo āpattiyo āpanno. Tā paṭidesemi. A: Passatha bhante? C: Āma āvuso, passāmi. A: Āyatiṁ bhante saṁvareyyātha. C: Sādhu suṭṭhu āvuso saṁvarissāmi.

rule_pali: omasavādasikkhāpadaṃ omasavāde pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk speaks abusively, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he is “aiming at Dhamma, aiming at (the person’s) benefit, aiming at teaching, if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: One insults a person directly to his face.. 2) Object: The person is a bhikkhu. 3) Intention: One's motive is to humiliate him.
notes: must be made directly to the listener. It may be phrased either as sarcastic praise or as out-and-out abuse. Indirect insults are wrong doing
formulas bmc 1: S. “I, friend, having many times fallen into grave  offences with different bases, these I confess J. Do you see, ven. sir? S. Yes, friend, I see J. In future, ven. sir, you should be restrained S. It is well indeed, friend. I shall be restrained

rule_pali: bhikkhupesuññe pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk engages in malicious talebearing between monks, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he is not making dear, if he is not desiring dissension, if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: Both Z's listener and X are bhikkhus; X has made remarks about Y that qualify as a direct insult under the preceding rule (or, if he didn't make them in Y's presence, remarks that would have qualified as a direct insult had he done so). 2) Effort: Z reports X's remarks to his listener verbally or by gesture (as in writing a letter), 3) Intent: with the intent of ingratiating himself with his listener, or of causing a rift between his listener and X
notes: Telling a bhikkhu about insulting remarks made by another bhikkhu—in hopes of winning favor or causing a rift
formulas bmc 1: For other categories of offenses, change dukkaṭāyo to thullaccayāyo, nissaggiyāyo pācittiyāyo, pācittiyāyo, or dubbhāsitāyo,

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu anupasampannaṃ padaso dhammaṃ vāceyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk instructs a person who is not fully ordained to recite the Teaching, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: in making (him) recite it together, in studying it together, if while speaking he drops a phrase usually familiar, if he drops it while expounding, if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: One gets a student to recite Dhamma line-by-line with oneself 2) Object: The student is neither a bhikkhu nor a bhikkhunī
notes: there was apparently the feeling that to teach non-ordainees to become skilled reciters of the texts was not good for the relationship between bhikkhus and the unordained.
formulas bmc 1: Cv 4 14.30 If the bhikkhu making confession is junior to the one acknowledging him,  (taking dukkaṭa as an example): Confessant: Ahaṁ bhante sambahulā nānā-vatthukāyo dukkaṭāyo āpattiyo āpanno. Tā paṭidesemi. Acknowledger: Passasi āvuso? C: Āma bhante, passāmi. A: Āyatiṁ āvuso saṁvareyyāsi. C: Sādhu suṭṭhu bhante saṁvarissāmi. (Three times.)

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu anupasampannena uttaridirattatirattaṃ sahaseyyaṃ kappeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk lies down in the same sleeping place as a person who is not fully ordained, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he stays for two or three nights; if he stays for less than two or three nights; if having stayed for two nights, departing before dawn on the third night, he stays again; if it is fully covered (but) not fully closed round; if it is fully closed round (but) not fully covered; if it is partially uncovered, partially not closed round; if the monk sits down while one who is not ordained is lying down; if one who is not ordained sits down while the monk is lying down; or if both sit down; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object an unordained person. 2) Effort: (a) lying down, (b) together in the same dwelling with the unordained person, (c) for four nights running
notes: original purpose was to avoid sleeping in the same place with an unordained person whenever possible. It would also be a wise policy to avoid sleeping out in a public park, and get up and meditate before dawn every day
formulas bmc 1: J. “I, ven. sir, having many times fallen into grave  offences with different bases, these I confess S. Do you see, friend? J. Yes, ven sir, I see S. In future, friend, you should be restrained J. It is well indeed, ven. sir. I shall be restrained

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu mātugāmena sahaseyyaṃ kappeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk lies down in the same sleeping place as a woman, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if it is fully covered (but) not fully closed round, if it is fully closed round (but) not fully covered, if it is partially uncovered, partially not closed round, if the monk sits down while the woman is lying down, if the woman sits down while the monk is lying down, or if both sit down; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object female human being 2) Effort: (a) lying down, (b) together in the same dwelling with the female human being  (c)  the instant he lies down in the same dwelling with her.
notes: any woman regardless of whether she is related to the bhikkhu. Even if another man is present in the dwelling. meant to protect bhikkhus and prevent suspicious situations of serious offense
formulas bmc 1: For other categories of offenses, change dukkaṭāyo to thullaccayāyo, nissaggiyāyo pācittiyāyo, pācittiyāyo, or dubbhāsitāyo,

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu mātugāmassa uttarichappañcavācāhi dhammaṃ deseyya aññatra viññunā purisaviggahena, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk gives a teaching of more than five or six sentences to a woman, except in the presence of a man who understands, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if a learned man (be present); if he teaches dhamma in five or six sentences; if he teaches dhamma in less than five or six sentences; if he teaches having risen, having sat down again; if the woman having risen sits down again, and he teaches at that (moment); if he is teaching a different woman; if she asks a question; if (she) having asked a question, he speaks; if talking for the good of another, a woman hears; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object a female human being who knows what is and is not lewd, what is well-spoken and ill-spoken, and who has not asked one a question about the Dhamma. 2) Effort: One teaches her more than six sentences of Dhamma without a knowledgeable man present — i.e., a male human being who also knows what is and is not lewd, what is well-spoken and ill-spoken.
notes: aimed at preventing a bhikkhu from using his knowledge of Dhamma as a way of making himself attractive to a woman. As any man who teaches Dhamma soon learns, there are women who find such knowledge irresistible. Prevent dangers male teachers female students
formulas bmc 1: Cv 4 14.30 Senior confesses : C: Ahaṁ āvuso sambahulā nānā-vatthukāyo dukkaṭāyo āpattiyo āpanno. Tā paṭidesemi. A: Passatha bhante? C: Āma āvuso, passāmi. A: Āyatiṁ bhante saṁvareyyātha. C: Sādhu suṭṭhu āvuso saṁvarissāmi.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu anupasampannassa uttarimanussadhammaṃ āroceyya, bhūtasmiṃ pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk truthfully tells a person who is not fully ordained of a superhuman quality, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he speaks of what is a fact to one who is ordained; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: One reports one's actual attainment of a superior human state 2) Object: to an unordained person, i.e., any human being who is not a bhikkhu or bhikkhunī.
formulas bmc 1: S. “I, friend, having many times fallen into grave  offences with different bases, these I confess J. Do you see, ven. sir? S. Yes, friend, I see J. In future, ven. sir, you should be restrained S. It is well indeed, friend. I shall be restrained

rule_pali: yopana bhikkhu bhikkhussa duṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ anupasampannassa āroceyya aññatra bhikkhusammutiyā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk tells a person who is not fully ordained about a monk’s grave offense, except if the monks have agreed, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he speaks of the class but not of an offence; if he speaks of an offence but not of the class; if there is the agreement of the monks; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object a serious offense committed by another bhikkhu. 2) Effort: One reports it to an unordained person without having been authorized to do so by the Community.
notes: to say, “Ven. Upananda committed a saṅghādisesa by masturbating,” is full offense; while to say simply, “Ven. Upananda committed a saṅghādisesa,” or “Ven. Upananda masturbated,” would not even wrong doing
formulas bmc 1: For other categories of offenses, change dukkaṭāyo to thullaccayāyo, nissaggiyāyo pācittiyāyo, pācittiyāyo, or dubbhāsitāyo,

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu pathaviṃ khaṇeyya vā khaṇāpeyya vā pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk digs the earth or has it dug, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he speaks, saying: “Find this, give this, convey this, this is wanted, make this allowable”; if it was unintentional, if (he was) not thinking, if he did not know, if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object. The Pali word for soil, paṭhavī, also means ground or earth.  2  Effort. The Vibhaṅga says that the term digging also covers burning,  3 Perception. If one perceives a patch of genuine soil not to be genuine soil, it is not grounds for an offense. If one is in doubt as to whether a patch of earth is classed as genuine soil, it is grounds for a dukkaṭa regardless of whether it is actually classed as genuine soil or not. 4 Intention to make a hole in the ground
notes: kappiya-vohāra—“allowable expression,” or  “wording it right” use in the context of rules where an express command would be an offense, but an indication of a desire or intent would not. This rule, together with the following one, also effectively prevents bhikkhus from engaging in agriculture.

rule_pali: bhūtagāmapātabyatāya pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk destroys plants, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he speaks, saying: “Find this, give this, convey this, this is wanted, make this allowable”; if it was unintentional, if (he was) not thinking, if he did not know; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a bhikkhu who should not be forced to move. 2) Perception: One perceives him as such. 3) Effort: One intrudes on his space in a dwelling belonging to the Community 4) Intention: with the sole purpose of forcing him out.
notes: algae, fungus, and mold would count as filth so remove them is not offense.  seedless fruit or fruit whose seeds may be removed entirely from the flesh of the fruit are allowable by themselves other fruit need “Kappiyaṁ karohi (Make it allowable).”
formulas bmc 1: Bu Pc 12 Evasion  Suṇātu me bhante saṅgho. Ayaṁ Itthannāmo bhikkhu saṅghamajjhe āpattiyā anuyuñjiyamāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicarati. Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṁ, saṅgho Itthannāmassa bhikkhuno aññavādakaṁ ropeyya. Esā ñatti.

rule_pali: aññavādake, vihesake pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk speaks evasively or harasses, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, not knowing, he asks; if, being ill, he does not speak; if, thinking: ‘Quarrel or dispute or strife or contention will come to be for the Order,’ he does not speak; if, thinking: ‘There will come to be schism in the Order or dissension in the Order,’ he does not speak; if, thinking: ‘He will carry out an (official) act according to what is not the rule, or by an incomplete congregation, or against one who is not suitable for an (official) act,’ he does not speak; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Intention: One’s motive is to hide one’s offenses. 2) Effort: One continues engaging in evasive speech or in causing frustration 3) Object: when being questioned in the Community about a rule or an offense after the Community has brought a formal charge of evasive speech or causing frustration against one.
notes: Sangha does formal charge of evasive speech or causing frustration. If he continues being uncooperative, he may further be subject to a more severe penalty, a censure transaction
formulas bmc 1: This Bhikkhu (name), when questioned in the midst of the Community about an offense, evades one question with another. If the Community is ready, it should make public Bhikkhu (name)’s evasive speech. This is the motion.

rule_pali: ujjhāpanake, khiyyanake pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk complains or criticizes, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he makes (someone) look down upon or if he criticises one acting by nature from desire, from hatred, from stupidity, from fear; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: (1) a bhikkhu who (2) has been properly authorized as a Community official and (3) does not habitually act out of the four causes for bias: desire, aversion, delusion, or fear. 2) Effort: criticizing or complaining about a Community official is a pācittiya if one’s listener is a fellow bhikkhu, and a dukkaṭa if listener is an unordained person 3) Intention: motive is to make him lose face, lose status, or feel abashed.
notes: wrong doing for criticism of unordained person, a Community official without having been authorized or having been improperly authorized,
formulas bmc 1: Bu Pc 12 Frustrating  Suṇātu me bhante saṅgho. Ayaṁ Itthannāmo bhikkhu saṅghamajjhe āpattiyā anuyuñjiyamāno tuṇhībhūto saṅghaṁ viheseti. Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṁ, saṅgho Itthannāmassa bhikkhuno vihesakaṁ ropeyya. Esā ñatti.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu saṅghike vihāre seyyaṃ santharitvā vā santharāpetvā vā taṃ pakkamanto neva uddhareyya, na uddharāpeyya, anāpucchaṃ vā gaccheyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk takes a bed, a bench, a mattress, or a stool belonging to the Sangha and puts it outside or has it put outside, and he then departs without putting it away, having it put away, or informing anyone, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, having removed it, he goes away; if, having caused it to be removed, he goes away; if, having asked (for permission), he goes away; if, drying himself in the sun, he goes away; if it comes to be taken possession of by something; if there are accidents; if it belongs to the individual himself, if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: any bed, bench, mattress, or stool belonging to the Community. 2) Effort: One sets such furnishings out in the open and then departs without taking leave, putting the furnishings away, or getting them put away in the proper place. 3) Intention: One has set them out for some purpose other than sunning them
notes: in dry season may also be kept in an open pavilion roofed with slats or branches, or under tree without droppings. Purpose is to prevent negligence and to teach one to care for things. It should be taken as a general model.”
formulas bmc 1: Bu Pc 12 Frustrating  Venerable sirs, may the Community listen to me. This Bhikkhu (name), when questioned in the midst of the Community about an offense, frustrates the Community by remaining silent. If the Community is ready, it should make public Bhikkhu (name)’s act of causing frustration. This is the motion.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu saṅghikaṃ mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā bhisiṃ vā kocchaṃ vā ajjhokāse santharitvā vā santharāpetvā vā taṃ pakkamanto neva uddhareyya, na uddharāpeyya, anāpucchaṃ vā gaccheyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk puts out bedding in a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, or has it put out, and he then departs without putting it away, having it put away, or informing anyone, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, having removed it, he goes away; if, having caused it to be removed, he goes away; if, having asked (for permission), he goes away; if it comes to be taken possession of by something; if going with the expectation, standing there, he asks (for permission); if he becomes taken possession of by something; if there are accidents; if belong to individual himself, if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: Bedding here includes mattresses, pillows, rugs, sheets, mats, sitting cloths, blankets, bedspreads, animal skins, throw rugs, etc., 2) Effort: One sets such bedding out in the open and then departs without taking leave, putting them away, or getting them put away in the proper place. 3) Intention: One has set them out and plans to return
notes: the bedding is the responsibility of the bhikkhu with the claim on the dwelling, and not of the visitor. putting it away is back in the safe place where it was kept before being spread out.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu saṅghike vihāre jānaṃ pubbupagataṃ bhikkhuṃ anupakhajja seyyaṃ kappeyya "yassa sambādho bhavissati, so pakkamissatī"ti etadeva paccayaṃ karitvā anaññaṃ, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If, in a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, a monk arranges his sleeping place in a way that encroaches on a monk that he knows arrived there before him, with the intention that anyone who feels crowded will leave, and he does so only for this reason and no other, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if an ill man enters, if one pressed by cold or by heat enters, if there are accidents; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer. dukkaṭa in telling someone else to evict the bhikkhu—
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a bhikkhu who should not be forced to move. 2) Perception: One perceives him as such. 3) Effort: One intrudes on his space in a dwelling belonging to the Community 4) Intention: with the sole purpose of forcing him out.
notes: Commentary defines as anywhere within 75 cm. of the sleeping or sitting place where one knows, “This bhikkhu shouldn’t be forced to move.”

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu bhikkhuṃ kupito anattamano saṅghikā vihārā nikkaḍḍheyya vā nikkaḍḍhāpeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk, in anger, throws a monk out of a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, or has him thrown out, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: in evicting anyone when one’s primary impulse is not anger, belongings from one’s own dwelling or one take on trust, if evicting anyone—or the requisites of anyone—who is insane, unconscientious in his/her behavior, or a maker of quarrels, strife, and dissension in the Community. if evict one’s student or his belongings from his dwelling if he is not properly observing his duties.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a bhikkhu. 2) Effort: One evicts him from a dwelling belonging to the Community. 3) Intention: One’s prime impulse is anger.
notes: bhikkhu is pācittiya,  while  dukkaṭa: a bhikkhu’s belongings, an unordained person, and an unordained person’s belongings.  dukkaṭa in telling someone else to evict the bhikkhu.  if one’s primary motive is greed, anger was simply a function of frustrated greed, and the two emotions would easily go together to infraction of this rule.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu saṅghike vihāre uparivehāsakuṭiyā āhaccapādakaṃ mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā abhinisīdeyya vā abhinipajjeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk sits down or lies down on a bed or a bench with detachable legs on an upper story in a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if there is no one under the loft; if the area under the loft cannot be used as a dwelling,  if the bed or bench with detachable legs is on the ground; or are securely fixed to their frame.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: loft is a partial second story in a dwelling; and bed or bench with detachable legs 2) Effort: sitting and lying down on it
notes: perhaps the Buddha’s purpose in formulating this rule was to discourage detachable legs their being placed in the loft in the first place.

rule_pali: mahallakaṃ pana bhikkhunā vihāraṃ kārayamānena yāva dvārakosā aggaḷaṭṭhapanāya ālokasandhiparikammāya dvatticchadanassa pariyāyaṃ appaharite ṭhitena adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ, tato ce uttari appaharitepi ṭhito adhiṭṭhaheyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: When a monk is building a large dwelling, then standing where there are no cultivated plants, he may apply two or three layers of roofing material, taking it as far as the doorcase and using it for fixing the door and for treating the window openings. If he applies more than that, even if he stands where there are no cultivated plants, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if there are two or three enclosures; if there are less than two or three enclosures; if it is in a cave, if it is in a hut, if it is in a tiṇa-grass hut; if it is for another; if it is by means of his own property; anything other than a dwelling, if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
notes: rule deals with techniques used in building dwellings 2,500 years ago, the Canon and commentaries contain terms whose meaning is uncertain at present. Aimed at preventing bhikkhus from abusing the generosity of the person sponsoring

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu jānaṃ sappāṇakaṃ udakaṃ tiṇaṃ vā mattikaṃ vā siñceyya vā siñcāpeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk pours water that he knows contains living beings onto grass or clay, or has it poured, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if it was unintentional, if he was not thinking, if he did not know; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: water contain living creatures  2) Perception: either knows on one’s own or has been told that the living creatures are there. 3) Effort: pouring the water or having it poured 4) Intention: aim of pouring the water or having it poured
notes: under this rule to prevent the pouring of lethal pollutants into water.  no allowance for kappiya-vohāra (“wording it right”) under this rule.

rule_pali: agilānena bhikkhunā eko āvasathapiṇḍo bhuñjitabbo. tato ce uttari bhuñjeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk who is not sick eats more than one alms-meal at a public guesthouse, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he is ill; if he eats once when he is not ill; if he eats going out or coming in; if the proprietors, having invited him, offer him food, if it is specially prepared (for him);  if the center determines the amount of food the recipients may take; setting  aside the five (kinds of) meals there is no offence in (eating) any others; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: public alms center is a place where all comers are offered as much food as they want, free of charge. 2 Effort: eating in the center two days running,
notes: eating in the same center two days running, To eat one day in one center and the next day in another entails no penalty.

rule_pali: gaṇabhojane aññatra samayā pācittiyaṃ. tatthāyaṃ samayo, gilānasamayo, cīvaradānasamayo, cīvarakārasamayo, addhānagamanasamayo, nāvābhiruhanasamayo, mahāsamayo, samaṇabhattasamayo, ayaṃ tattha samayo.
rule_english: If a monk eats in a group, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession. These are the appropriate occasions: he is sick; it is the robe-giving season; it is a time of making robes; he is traveling; he is on a boat; it is a big occasion; it is a meal given by a monastic
no_offense_factors: if it is at a right time; if two or three eat together; if having walked one by one for alms, they eat having assembled together; if it is the regular supply of food; if it is food (allowed by) ticket; if it is (food given) on a day of the waxing or waning of the moon,if it is (given) on an Observance day, or the day after; setting aside the five (kinds of) meals, there is no offence in (eating) any other; if donor is from other religions; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: group meal consist of any of the five types of staple foods to which four or more bhikkhus are invited. 2 Effort: applies exclusively to invitations to specific groups—not Communities—of four or more bhikkhus regardless of whether the invitation mentions the word “food” or “meal.” 3 Intention: specify the names or groups of bhikkhus to be invited.
notes: Purposes are “For the restraint of evil-minded individuals, for the comfort of well-behaved bhikkhus, so that those with evil desires will not split the Community by (forming) a faction, and out of compassion for families.”

english_name: Accepting Two or Three Bowls Full
rule_pali: bhikkhuṃ paneva kulaṃ upagataṃ pūvehi vā manthehi vā abhihaṭṭhuṃ pavāreyya, ākaṅkhamānena bhikkhunā dvattipattapūrā paṭiggahetabbā. tato ce uttari paṭiggaṇheyya, pācittiyaṃ. dvattipattapūre paṭiggahetvā tato nīharitvā bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ saṃvibhajitabbaṃ, ayaṃ tattha sāmīci.
rule_english: If a monk goes to a family and is invited to take pastries or baked goods, he may accept two or three bowlfuls if he wishes. If he accepts more than that, he commits an offense entailing confession. If he accepts two or three bowlfuls, he should take it away and share it with the monks. This is the proper procedure
no_offense_factors: if he accepts two or three bowlfuls or less; if they give what is prepared neither as a present nor as provisions for a journey; if they give the remainder of what is prepared either as a present or as provisions for a journey; if they give because the journey is given up; if they belong to relations; if they are invited; if they are for the good of another; if it is by means of his own property; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: Receiving more than three bowlfuls 2) Object: of cakes or cooked grain-meal (sattu), use as presents or as provisions for a journey
notes: The purpose of this rule is to prevent bhikkhus from abusing a donor’s generosity and good faith.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu vikāle khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā khādeyya vā bhuñjeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk eats fresh or cooked food at the wrong time, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: offense if, having a reason, one consumes juice drinks, any of the five tonics, medicine, or water after noon or before dawnrise; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: staple or non-staple food that is not leftover. 2) Effort: chew or consume staple or non-staple food at the wrong time
notes: No exception is granted to an ill bhikkhu, because there are a number of edibles an ill bhikkhu may consume at the wrong time without involving an offense: juice drinks, the five tonics, and medicines.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṃ khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā khādeyya vā bhuñjeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk eats fresh or cooked food that he has stored, he commits an offense entailing confession.
no_offense_factors: if , having stored (food) for the time being, he eats it in that time; if, having stored (food to be eaten) during a watch of the night, he eats  it in a watch of the night; if, having stored (food) to be eaten during seven days, he eats it in seven days; if, when there is a reason, he uses (food to be eaten) during life; if he is mad; if he is the first wrong-doer, in the mere act of storing food.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: staple or non-staple food that is not leftover. Stored-up means formally accepted by a bhikkhu on one day and eaten on the next or a later day. 2) Effort: chew or consume staple or non-staple food at the wrong time
notes: monasteries leftovers from the bhikkhus‘ meals may not be served to the bhikkhus again on a later day. Large portions can be offered separately day by day. no offense in telling an unordained person to store food that has not been formally received.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu adinnaṃ mukhadvāraṃ āhāraṃ āhareyya aññatra udakadantaponā, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk eats food that has not been given, except for water and tooth cleaners, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: in regard to water for cleansing the teeth; if himself, having taken the four foul things, he makes use of them when there is a reason (and if) there is no one to make them allowable; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: edible is whatever is fit to eat, that has not been given. 2 Effort: dukkaṭa if, with the intention of eating it, he takes food that hasn’t been properly given; and a pācittiya for every mouthful he eats.
notes: allowance in Cv 5 26  states that if food accidentally falls while being offered, a bhikkhu may pick it up himself and eat it without committing an offense.
useful_texts: Cv 5 26 allowance, fallen fruit Mv 6 17.8-9; Mv 6 32

english_name: Sending a Bhikkhu Back from Almsround
rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu bhikkhuṃ "ehāvuso, gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisissāmā"ti tassa dāpetvā vā adāpetvā vā uyyojeyya "gacchāvuso, na me tayā saddhiṃ kathā vā nisajjā vā phāsu hoti, ekakassa me kathā vā nisajjā vā phāsu hotī"ti etadeva paccayaṃ karitvā anaññaṃ, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk says to a monk, “Come, let’s go to the village or town for alms,” and then, whether he has had food given to him or not, sends him away, saying, “Go away, I’m not comfortable talking or sitting with you, but only if I talk and sit by myself,” and he does so only for this reason and no other, he commits an offense entailing confession.’
no_offense_factors: if dismissing one’s companion with the thought that two bhikkhus going together won’t obtain enough food; dismissing him after seeing costly goods ahead, so that he won’t develop a feeling of greed; dismissing him after seeing a beautiful woman ahead, so that he won’t lose his resolve for the celibate life; sending him back with food for one who is sick, who was left behind, or who is guarding the monastery; or dismissing him for any other proper reason as long as one is not planning to indulge in misconduct; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: another bhikkhu. 2) Intention: One wants to indulge in misconduct and does not want him to see it. 3) Effort: One dismisses him. 4) Result: He leaves one’s range of hearing and sight.
notes: the factors for this offense apply in any location and at any time of the day.
formulas bmc 1: This pattern—three pācittiyas and three dukkaṭas—is repeated in all the rules where a bhikkhu is grounds for a pācittiya, an unordained person is grounds for a dukkaṭa, and perception is not a mitigating factor.

english_name: Intruding on a Couple Enjoying Themselves
rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu sabhojane kule anupakhajja nisajjaṃ kappeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk sits down intruding on a lustful couple, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if both the man and woman have left the bedroom/private area; if neither of them is sexually aroused; if the building is not a “sleeping building”; if the bhikkhu is not in the private area; if he has a companion.; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: a couple together in their private quarters, with at least one of them desiring sexual intercourse with the other. 2 Effort: to sit—without another bhikkhu present—in the private area of the house,
notes: a bhikkhu should not sit intruding on a couple unless they both make him 100% certain that he is welcome.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu mātugāmena saddhiṃ raho paṭicchanne āsane nisajjaṃ kappeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk sits down in private on a concealed seat with a woman, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if some learned friend comes to be (present); if he stands, does not sit; if he is not desirous of a private place; if he sits down thinking about something else; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: One sits with her alone—without another person present—in a place private to the ear and to the eye, and secluded. 2) Object: woman is defined as female human being who knows what is properly an what is lewd. Paṇḍakas, female petas, female yakkhas, and animals in the form of a woman are grounds for a dukkaṭa. 3) Intention: One must be aiming at privacy for this factor to be fulfilled.
notes: Woman here includes women as well. In other words, even if one is sitting with many women in the secluded area. even when his motives are pure, he is inviting the suspicions of others. the woman, may make any claims she likes about what went on while they were alone together.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu mātugāmena saddhiṃ eko ekāya raho nisajjaṃ kappeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk sits down in private alone with a woman, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if some learned friend comes to be (present); if he stands, does not sit; if he is not desirous of a private place; if he sits down thinking about something else; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: One sits with her alone—without another person present—in a place private to the ear and to the eye, but not secluded. 2) Object: woman is defined as female human being who knows what is properly an what is lewd. Paṇḍakas, female petas, female yakkhas, and animals in the form of a woman are grounds for a dukkaṭa. 3) Intention: One must be aiming at privacy for this factor to be fulfilled.
notes: If it would be convenient for committing sexual intercourse, it would fall under the preceding rule; if not, it would fall here. In this rule the other person whose presence exempts one from this factor can be either a man or a woman.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu nimantito sabhatto samāno santaṃ bhikkhuṃ anāpucchā purebhattaṃ vā pacchābhattaṃ vā kulesu cārittaṃ āpajjeyya aññatra samayā, pācittiyaṃ. tatthāyaṃ samayo, cīvaradānasamayo, cīvarakārasamayo, ayaṃ tattha samayo
rule_english: If a monk who has been invited to a meal visits families beforehand or afterwards without informing an available monk, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession. These are the appropriate occasions: it is the robe-giving season; it is a time of making robes
no_offense_factors: if at the right time, he enters having asked (for permission) if a monk be there; if he enters not having asked (for permission) if a monk be not there; if the way is through the house of another; or the precincts of a house; if he is going into a village; if he is going to the nuns’ quarters; if he is going to a sleeping-place of adherents of other sects; if he is returning from these places; if he is going to a house for food; if there are accidents; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a family residence. 2) Effort: One enters such a residence—without having taken leave of an available bhikkhu—on a morning when one has been invited to a meal, except during the time exemptions mentioned in the rule.
notes: The purpose is to prevent bhikkhus from taking the invitation as an excuse to visit lay people and spend their time in inappropriate activities. if one is without dependance (nissya) taking leave in the context of this rule means the simple act of informing the other bhikkhu not asking for permission.

rule_pali: agilānena bhikkhunā catumāsappaccayapavāraṇā sāditabbā aññatra punapavāraṇāya, aññatra niccapavāraṇāya. tato ce uttari sādiyeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: A monk who is not sick may accept an invitation to ask for requisites for four months. If he accepts one beyond that limit, except if it is a further invitation or a permanent invitation, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he asks for those medicines which he came to be invited (to accept); if he asks for those nights for which he came to be invited (to accept); if he asks, explaining, ‘Of those medicines which we were invited by you (to accept) we need this and that medicine’; if he asks, explaining, ‘Those nights for which we were invited by you have passed and we need medicine’; if they belong to relations; if they are invited; if it is for the sake of another; if it is by means of his own property; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: medicine that a donor has invited a Community to request. 2) Effort: One requests it outside of the terms of the invitation when one is not ill.
notes: person making the invitation was expected to provide the goods he offered, while bhikkhus were expected to be reasonable in their requests. Normally, an ill bhikkhu may ask anyone for medicine at any time,

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu uyyuttaṃ senaṃ dassanāya gaccheyya aññatra tathārūpappaccayā, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk goes to see an army, except if there is a suitable reason, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, having gone on business, one sees the army; if, standing within a monastery, one watches an army fighting or holding practice maneuvers nearby; if an army comes to where one happens to be; if one meets an army coming from the opposite direction; or if there are dangers.
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: army in active duty  2 Effort: fulfilled simply by staying still and watching an army on duty except when one has a suitable reason. 3 Intention: Suitable reason might be to visit a relative in the army that is ill
notes: Armies not on active duty, as when they organize charity events, would not be grounds for an offense.

rule_pali: siyā ca tassa bhikkhuno kocideva paccayo senaṃ gamanāya, dirattatirattaṃ tena bhikkhunā senāya vasitabbaṃ. tato ce uttari vaseyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If that monk has a reason for going to the army, he may stay with the army for two or three nights. If he stays longer than that, he commits an offense entailing confession.’
no_offense_factors: in staying longer than three nights if they are not consecutive, or in staying longer than three consecutive nights: if one is ill or caring for someone else who is ill; if the army is surrounded by opposing forces; if one is being constrained; or if there are other dangers
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: army in active duty  2 Effort: stay two or three (consecutive) nights with the army.
notes: this rule does not apply to the housing where military officers live with their families, whether on base or off.

rule_pali: dirattatirattaṃ ce bhikkhu senāya vasamāno uyyodhikaṃ vā balaggaṃ vā senābyūhaṃ vā anīkadassanaṃ vā gaccheyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk who is staying with an army for two or three nights goes to a battle, a troop review, a massing of the army, or a troop inspection, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, having gone on business, one sees the army; if, standing within a monastery, one watches an army fighting or holding practice maneuvers nearby; if an army comes to where one happens to be; if one meets an army coming from the opposite direction; or if there are dangers.
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: army in active duty  2 Effort: go to a battlefield, a roll call, the troops in battle formation, or to see a review of the (battle) units,
notes: using the Great Standards, we may say that any show the armed forces put on for the public—parades, air shows, etc.—would also be offense here

rule_pali: surāmerayapāne pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: ‘If a monk drinks this or that kind of alcoholic drink, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he drinks that which is not strong drink though it comes to be the colour of strong drink, the smell of strong drink, the taste of strong drink; if eat dishes to which alcoholic beverages, such as wine, are added for flavoring before they are cooked;. if he drinks a distilled liquor that is not strong drink; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: any alcoholic beverages  2 Effort: Consume it, even as little as the tip of a blade of grass.
notes: alcohol is criticized for it destroys one’s sense of shame, weakens one’s discernment, and can put one into a stupor, so it seems reasonable to extend this rule to other intoxicants, narcotics, and hallucinogens with these effects as well. Coffee, tea, tobacco, and betel do not have this effect, though.

rule_pali: aṅgulipatodake pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk tickles someone, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, not desiring laughter, he rubs (him) if there is something to be done; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: another bhikkhu. any unordained person, grounds for a dukkaṭa. 2) Effort: One touches any part of his body with any part of one’s own body 3) Intention: for fun.
notes: if a bhikkhu massaging another bhikkhu’s tired back commits no offense if he inadvertently happens to touch a spot where the other bhikkhu is ticklish.

rule_pali: udake hasadhamme pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk plays in water, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, not desiring laughter, plunging into the water if there is something to be done, or if, going to the other side, he immerses or draws out or swims; if there are accidents; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: One jumps up or down, splashes, or swims 2) Object: in water deep enough to immerse one’s ankle 3) Intention: for fun.
notes: swimming for fitness or exercise is not discussed in any of the texts

rule_pali: anādariye pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: ‘If a monk is disrespectful, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, being admonished, one states simply that one was taught differently by one’s teachers.; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: Having been admonished by a fellow bhikkhu who cites a rule formulated in the Vinaya is Paccitiya; or for sake of being “self-effacing, scrupulous, inspiring; for lessening (defilement) or arousing energy” that are not formulated is wrong doing if  one shows disrespect 2) Object: for the bhikkhu or for the rule.
notes: wise policy would be to avoid showing disrespect for another person, regardless of the situation. if one expresses disrespect behind his or her back, it would count as offense here

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu bhikkhuṃ bhiṃsāpeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk scares a monk, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, not desirous of frightening, he arranges a form or a sound or a smell or a taste or a touch, or points out the dangers of thieves or of beasts of prey or ghost; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Intention: One wants to frighten the other person. 2 Effort: One arranges a frightening sight, sound, smell, taste, or tactile sensation or one describes dangers from ghosts, robbers, or wild animals. 3 Object: The other person is a bhikkhu. Anyone who is not a bhikkhu is grounds for a dukkaṭa.
notes: “Result” is not a factor here. If the three factors are fulfilled, one commits the offense regardless of whether the other person is actually frightened.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu agilāno visibbanāpekkho jotiṃ samādaheyya vā samādahāpeyya vā aññatra tathārūpappaccayā, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk who is not sick lights a fire to warm himself, or has one lit, except if there is a suitable reason, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he is ill; if he warms himself at one made by another; if he warms himself over raked-out embers; if at a lamp, in a fire-room, in a bath-room; if there is a sufficient reason for it; if there are dangers; if he is mad; if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: One is not ill.  2) Effort: One lights a fire or gets someone else to light one 3) Intention: for the purpose of warming oneself.
notes: Solar or electric heating systems, which do not use flames, would not be included here.
useful_texts: Fire disadvantages AN 5:219, fire hall Cv 5 14.1

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu orenaddhamāsaṃ nahāyeyya aññatra samayā, pācittiyaṃ. tatthāyaṃ samayo "diyaḍḍho māso seso gimhāna"nti "vassānassa paṭhamo māso" iccete aḍḍhateyyamāsā uṇhasamayo, pariḷāhasamayo, gilānasamayo, kammasamayo, addhānagamanasamayo, vātavuṭṭhisamayo, ayaṃ tattha samayo
rule_english: If a monk bathes at intervals of less than a half-month, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession. These are the appropriate occasions: it is the two-and-a-half-month period of the hot season and the fever season, comprising the last one-and-a-half months of summer and the first month of the rainy season; he is sick; he is working; he is traveling; there is wind and rain
no_offense_factors: if it is at a right time; if he bathes at (intervals of) the half-month o more than half a month; if he bathes going to the further bank; if he is in nothing but bordering districts; if there are accidents; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Effort: Bathing more frequently than once a fortnight when residing in the middle Ganges Valley, except on certain occasions.
notes: According to Mv 5 13 there is nowhere in the world outside of the middle Ganges Valley where this rule applies.

rule_pali: navaṃ pana bhikkhunā cīvaralābhena tiṇṇaṃ dubbaṇṇakaraṇānaṃ aññataraṃ dubbaṇṇakaraṇaṃ ādātabbaṃ nīlaṃ vā kaddamaṃ vā kāḷasāmaṃ vā. anādā ce bhikkhu tiṇṇaṃ dubbaṇṇakaraṇānaṃ aññataraṃ dubbaṇṇakaraṇaṃ navaṃ cīvaraṃ paribhuñjeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: When a monk gets a new robe, he should apply one of three kinds of stains: blue-green, mud-color, or dark brown. If a monk uses a new robe without applying any of the three kinds of stains, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if, having taken, he makes use of it; if what is allowable becomes destroyed; if what made the appearance allowable becomes worn away; if what was not made allowable becomes sewn together with what was made allowable; if there is a patch; if there is a braiding; if there is a binding hem; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object:a new robe;  2 Effort: one makes use of it without first marking it.
notes: a bhikkhu should wear robes only that have been marked with an identifying mark. This doesn't include sitting cloths, handkerchiefs, or shoulder bags. The Commentary details and prohibitions have no basis in the Canon or the Great Standards, they are not binding.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā sikkhamānāya vā sāmaṇerassa vā sāmaṇeriyā vā sāmaṃ cīvaraṃ vikappetvā appaccuddhāraṇaṃ paribhuñjeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk himself assigns the ownership of a robe to a monk, to a nun, to a trainee nun, to a novice monk, or to a novice nun, and he then uses it without the other first relinquishing it, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he gives it, or if putting his trust in him, if the shared ownership has been rescinded then he makes use of it; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.  for legitimately taking an item on trust are as follows (Mv 8 19.1): 1) The other person is a friend. 2) He/she is an intimate. 3) He/she has spoken of the matter.  4) He/she is still alive. 5) One knows that he/she will be pleased at one’s taking it.
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: any one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, measuring at least four by eight fingerbreadths, that one has placed under shared ownership;  2 Effort: one uses the cloth without the shared ownership’s being rescinded.
notes: Cloth that has not been made into a finished robe, rains-bathing cloths being kept outside of the rainy season, and skin-eruption covering cloths being kept when they are not needed, may all be placed under shared ownership for any length of time. The three basic robes, miscellaneous requisites, handkerchiefs, and the sitting cloth may not.
formulas bmc 1: “I place this robe-cloth under shared ownership with you (plural)” or “with so-and-so.” To rescinde ownership the second owner to say: “Use what is mine, give it away, or do as you like with it.”
useful_texts: Shred ownershipBu Np 1.  Mv 8 20.2,  8 21.1.  On trust Mv 5 13.13, Mv 8 31.2-3, Mv 8 19.1, Bu Pj 2

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu bhikkhussa pattaṃ vā cīvaraṃ vā nisīdanaṃ vā sūcigharaṃ vā kāyabandhanaṃ vā apanidheyya vā apanidhāpeyya vā antamaso hasāpekkhopi, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk hides a monk’s bowl, robe, sitting mat, needle case, or belt, or he has it hidden, even just for a laugh, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he is not desiring fun; if he puts in order what is badly arranged; if he puts it in order, thinking, ‘I will give it back, having given dhamma-talk’; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: Any of the requisites mentioned in the rule, belonging to a bhikkhu. 2 Effort: One hides the article or has it hidden. 3 Intention: One is doing it as a game.
notes: Any requisite not mentioned in the rule but belonging to a bhikkhu is grounds for a dukkaṭa, as is any requisite belonging to a person who is not a bhikkhu.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk intentionally kills a living being, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if it is unintentional; if (he is) not thinking; if he does not know; if he is not meaning death; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a living animal. 2) Perception: One perceives it to be a living animal. 3) Intention: One knowingly, consciously, deliberately, and purposefully wants to cause its death. 4) Effort: whatever one does with the purpose of causing it to die. 5) Result: It dies as a result of one’s action.
notes: smallest extreme to which this rule extends is a bed bug egg.  Even the desire to kill an animal to “put it out of its misery” fulfills the factor of intention all the same. no room for kappiya-vohāra there is a dukkaṭa for the first effort that touches the animal’s body; another dukkaṭa if the animal experiences pain because of one’s effort; and the full offense if, as a result, it dies.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu jānaṃ sappāṇakaṃ udakaṃ paribhuñjeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: If a monk uses water that he knows contains living beings, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he makes use of it not knowing that it contains living things, knowing that it does not contain living things, knowing that they will not die from this use; if he is mad, if he is the first wrongdoer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: Water containing living creatures. 2 Perception: One knows that they are there 3 Effort: all cases of using water containing living beings that are not covered by Pc 20.
notes: non-offense clauses here make no exception for a bhikkhu who uses water containing living beings either unthinkingly or unintentionally. Do not include  the act of getting other people to use such water under this rule. Result is not a factor here.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu jānaṃ yathādhammaṃ nihatādhikaraṇaṃ punakammāya ukkoṭeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk reopens a legal issue that he knows has been legitimately settled, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he opens it up knowingly, thinking: ‘The (formal) act was carried out according to what is not the rule, or by an incomplete congregation, or against one who is not suitable for a (formal) act’; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: an issue that has been dealt with properly. 2) Perception: One knows that it was dealt with properly, either because one was directly involved or one has been told of the matter. 3) Effort: One says—in the presence of another bhikkhu—that it was dealt with improperly.
notes: An issue (adhikaraṇa) is a matter that,  must be dealt with formally in a prescribed manner.  1) dispute-issues (vivādādhikaraṇa) concerning Dhamma and Vinaya (see Sg 10), Community declare  which side is right and which wrong; 2) accusation-issues (anuvādādhikaraṇa) concerning offenses (see Sg 8 & 9; Ay 1 & 2),  Community judge them true or false; 3) offense-issues (āpattādhikaraṇa), the commission of offenses and  their penalties (confession, penance, or expulsion from the Community);  4) duty-issues (kiccādhikaraṇa)—Community transactions, such ordination and holding the Pāṭimokkha recitation
useful_texts: procedures are discussed under Pc 79 & 80, the Adhikaraṇa-samatha rules, and in BMC2, Chapters 12-22

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu jānaṃ theyyasatthena saddhiṃ saṃvidhāya ekaddhānamaggaṃ paṭipajjeyya antamaso gāmantarampi, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk knowingly travels by arrangement with a group of thieves, even just to the next village, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if the bhikkhu and thieves happen to travel together without having made an arrangement; if the thieves propose an arrangement, but the bhikkhu does not give his verbal assent; if the bhikkhu leaves not as specified in the arrangement; or if there are dangers; if he is mad
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a caravan of thieves. 2) Perception: One knows that it is a caravan of thieves—either from knowing on one’s own, from having been told by one of the thieves, or from having been told by others. 3) Effort: (a) Having made an arrangement together with the caravan to travel together, (b) one actually travels together with them as arranged (c) from one village to another.
notes: thieves are who committed a theft, is on its way to commit a theft, is planning to evade a tax, or is planning to cheat the government in one way or another. Any expressed agreement to go together would fulfill this factor, regardless of whether the time frame is explicitly stated.

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu evaṃ vadeyya "tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā yeme antarāyikā dhammā vuttā bhagavatā, te paṭisevato nālaṃ antarāyāyā"ti, so bhikkhu bhikkhūhi evamassa vacanīyo "māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya, anekapariyāyenāvuso antarāyikā dhammā antarāyikā vuttā bhagavatā, alañca pana te paṭisevato antarāyāyā"ti. evañca so bhikkhu bhikkhūhi vuccamāno tatheva paggaṇheyya, so bhikkhu bhikkhūhi yāvatatiyaṃ samanubhāsitabbo tassa paṭinissaggāya. yāvatatiyañce samanubhāsiyamāno taṃ paṭinissajjeyya, iccetaṃ kusalaṃ. no ce paṭinissajjeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk says, “As I understand the Buddha’s Teaching, the things he calls obstacles are unable to obstruct one who indulges in them,” then the monks should correct him like this: “No, Venerable, don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for it’s not good to misrepresent the Buddha. The Buddha would never say such a thing. In many discourses the Buddha has declared the obstacles to be obstructive and how they obstruct one who indulges in them.” If that monk continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him give up that view. If he then gives it up, all is well. If he does not, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he is not admonished; if he gives it up; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: Simply holding such a view is not enough to bring a bhikkhu under the purview of this rule, but if he asserts it to others, the Vibhaṅga states that other bhikkhus have the duty of reprimanding him up to three times in the manner described in the rule. If, having learned of his assertion, they do not reprimand him, they each incur a dukkaṭa, for if he goes unreprimanded, he may continue with his assertions as he likes without incurring a penalty. A Community preparing to impose this rule on a stubborn bhikkhu should also be prepared to impose a suspension transaction on him immediately in case he refuses to respond to the formal rebuke.
notes: If, after being reprimanded, he relinquishes his view, he incurs no penalty. But if he doesn’t, he incurs a dukkaṭa. He should then be taken into the midst of the Community to be admonished and rebuked as described under Sg 10, the only difference here being that the penalty is a dukkaṭa in each of the preliminary stages, and a pācittiya after the third formal rebuke. (The formula for the rebuke is given in Appendix VIII BMC 1) If a bhikkhu penalized under this rule persists in asserting his evil view, he is subject to an act of suspension, under which he is not allowed to commune or affiliate with bhikkhus in any Community until he sees the error of his ways and relinquishes his view (see BMC2, Chapter 20
formulas bmc 1: Venerable sirs, may the Community listen to me. An evil viewpoint of this sort has arisen in Bhikkhu (name): “As I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One, those acts the Blessed One says are obstructive, when engaged in are not genuine obstructions.” He does not relinquish that view. If the Community is ready, it should rebuke Bhikkhu (name) for the sake of relinquishing that view. This is the motion. 3 times Bhikkhu (name) has been rebuked by the Community for the sake of relinquishing that view. This is agreeable to the Community, therefore it is silent. Thus do I hold it. Apendix XIII BMC 1
useful_texts: obstructions in MN 54, AN 5.76, AN 6:86. AN 6:87, SN 6.10. BU Pc 69-70

rule_pali: yo pana bhikkhu jānaṃ tathāvādinā bhikkhunā akaṭānudhammena taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissaṭṭhena saddhiṃ sambhuñjeyya vā, saṃvaseyya vā, saha vā seyyaṃ kappeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: If a monk lives, does formal meetings, or shares a sleeping place with a monk who he knows is saying such things, who has not made amends according to the rule, and who has not given up that view, he commits an offense entailing confession
no_offense_factors: if he knows, “He is not suspended”; if he knows, “He was suspended, he is restored”; if he knows, “He has given up that view”; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a bhikkhu who has been suspended by a Community transaction and has not yet been restored. 2) Perception: One knows that he has been suspended and has not yet been restored 3) Effort: One communes with him, affiliates with him, or lies down in the same dwelling with him.
notes: According to Cv.I.25-35, a bhikkhu may be suspended for: 1 He refuses to relinquish an evil view, as in the preceding rule; 2 he refuses to see an offense; or 3 he refuses to make amends for an offense
formulas bmc 1: Suṇātu me bhante saṅgho. Itthannāmassa bhikkhuno evarūpaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ uppannaṁ, “Tathāhaṁ bhagavatā dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāmi, yathā ye’me antarāyikā dhammā vuttā bhagavatā, te paṭisevato nālaṁ antarāyāyā” ti. So taṁ diṭṭhiṁ nappaṭinissajjati. Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṁ, saṅgho Itthannāmaṁ bhikkhuṁ samanubhāseyya tassā diṭṭhiyā paṭinissaggāya. Esā ñatti.
useful_texts: Bu Pc 68, 70 Suspension Cv.I.25-35, BMC2 Chapter 20.

rule_pali: samaṇuddesopi ce evaṃ vadeyya "tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā yeme antarāyikā dhammā vuttā bhagavatā, te paṭisevato nālaṃ antarāyāyā"ti, so samaṇuddeso bhikkhūhi evamassa vacanīyo "māvuso, samaṇuddesa evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya, anekapariyāyenāvuso, samaṇuddesa antarāyikā dhammā antarāyikā vuttā bhagavatā, alañca pana te paṭisevato antarāyāyā"ti, evañca so samaṇuddeso bhikkhūhi vuccamāno tatheva paggaṇheyya, so samaṇuddeso bhikkhūhi evamassa vacanīyo "ajjatagge te, āvuso, samaṇuddesa na ceva so bhagavā satthā apadisitabbo, yampi caññe samaṇuddesā labhanti bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ dirattatirattaṃ sahaseyyaṃ, sāpi te natthi, cara pire, vinassā"ti. yo pana bhikkhu jānaṃ tathānāsitaṃ samaṇuddesaṃ upalāpeyya vā, upaṭṭhāpeyya vā, sambhuñjeyya vā, saha vā seyyaṃ kappeyya, pācittiyaṃ
rule_english: Also if a novice monastic says, “As I understand the Buddha’s Teaching, the things he calls obstacles are unable to obstruct one who indulges in them,” then the monks should correct him like this: “No, don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for it’s not good to misrepresent the Buddha. The Buddha would never say such a thing. In many discourses the Buddha has declared the obstacles to be obstructive and how they obstruct one who indulges in them.” If that novice monastic continues as before, he should be told: “From today on you may not refer to the Buddha as your teacher. And you can no longer share a sleeping place with the monks for two or three nights, as can other novice monastics. Go! Away with you!” If a monk befriends that novice monastic, or he is attended on by him, lives with him, or shares a sleeping place with him, even though he knows that he has been expelled in this way, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
no_offense_factors: if he knows, “He is not expelled”; if he knows, “He has given up that view”; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer.
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a novice who has been expelled and has not relinquished his evil view. 2) Perception: One perceives that he has been expelled and has not relinquished his evil view—either from knowing on one’s own, from having been told by him (§), or from having been told by others. 3) Effort: One befriends him, receives services from him, communes with him, or lies down in the same dwelling with him
notes: A novice comes to think that there is nothing wrong with any novice’s having sexual intercourse or breaking any of his other precepts. This form of expulsion lasts as long as he has yet to relinquish his view. If and when he does relinquish it, he is to be reinstated.
